An instant icon of the city from the moment it was completed in 1931, the Empire State Building cost a paltry $645 million dollars to erect (adjusted for inflation), and is still the fifth-tallest building in the United States.
The Triborough Bridge, connecting the boroughs of Manhattan, Queens, and the Bronx where they meet at Ward's Island, was erected in 1936 at the equivalent of $1 billion in today's dollars.
The current Grand Central Terminal, the largest railroad station in the world, was erected in 1913, for the equivalent of $2 billion today.

The Holland Tunnel connects New Jersey to New York by car. It was finished in 1927 at a cost equivalent to $3.3 billion today.
The spine-backed Oculus was opened to the public on March 4, 2016 to a mixed reception due to its extreme cost - $4 billion dollars.
Phase one of the Second Avenue Subway opened on New Year's Day 2017. It added three uptown lines and cost $4.5 billion.
Phase two of the Second Avenue Subway is to cost $6 billion. But is that too much?
The MTA's entire five-year capital budget plan weighs in at $10.8 billion - less than half the cost of Phase 2.
